topics.body:
Well it's pretty official that Hillary is going to be the next president:
Short version is that she's for certain going to get the democrat's nomination in that she's going to get anywhere from 60% of the caucuses' votes to 70%; no one else would come close to getting the Democrat nomination to the point it would be over within the first couple of states.

The other thing is that Republicans don't have a single electable person lined up for the general election.  The closest scenario is Hillary ONLY winning 60% of the general election and ONLY winning at least 300 electoral votes.  That's a extreme bias in Republican's favor though.  The most realistic scenario though is she'll more than likely win nearly 400 electoral votes.  The scenarios get worse when you calculate in potential Republican contenders in the caucuses and how in all probability the Republican candidate will win big with conservatives but be totally unelectable in the general election.


If you're wondering where I'm going with this:  Hillary in 2016 will win anywhere from 300 electoral votes to 450 depending on who she's running against.

Tl:dr; 2016 R.I.P. GOP
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53b3999363687252be910100#post_53b3999363687252be910100
Conservatism is in a weird, weak place right now.

At its heart being conservative means that you believe things ought not to change or that they should even revert to an older time, and as the generations change so does what exactly it means to be conservative change.

Presently it is deeply fractured because some strains of conservatism that were once strong are dying out as the people who believed in them are.

topics.body:
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53b39fc26368726583f60000#post_53b39fc26368726583f60000
Looked at from the other direction you could also say that the democrats don't offer a genuine alternative to the right wing party.

My broader point is this. While conservatism is weak in the US now, it won't be forever. It will make a comeback, probably before the decade is out though it taking longer is certainly not impossible.

Now, whether or not the republicans are still the face of American conservatism I can't say, though frankly we're long past due for a political upheaval of this magnitude.

Of course all of this is predicated on the idea that there will be a spontaneous erosion of voter apathy in the next few elections, so ultimately who can say?

Fuck there is still time for a massive upset to come along in the upcoming one, but whether one happens or not I know one thing: 2015 is going to hurt me.
